subject: Some Berry Good News For Windows Users
header: This week we have something that is bound to make our Windows-using brethren happy: berrybrew, a perlbrew/plenv equivalent for Strawberry Perl, by David Farrell. We also have a few nice grant reports. And, in the everlasting fun department, Sinan's playing with quines lead to dark archaeological discoveries about 'open' and 'autodie'. Enjoy!  Oh, and if you are based in Canada, happy Thanksgiving! ~ `/anick

entries.title: Hello berrybrew, the Strawberry Perl version manager
entries.text: Windows users, prepare to squeal in glee. David Farrell introduces his berrybrew, a Strawberry Perl version manager (think perlbrew/plenv, but for the Windows platform).

entries.title: 10 ways of implementing Polymorphism
entries.text: Caleb Cushing reviews the -- fittingly -- many ways that can be used to implement polymorphism.

entries.title: Travis-CI Helpers for Perl
entries.text: Want to harness the full power of Travis-CI for your Perl projects? Graham Knop has a few helper tools that will assist you on your quest for the Continuous Integration Grail.

entries.title: Building Ansible Modules with Perl and Mojolicious
entries.text: Ansible is one of those snazzy tools that automate the installation and management of software/configuration/all the things on armies of machines. It's written in Python, but works well with components written in anything else.  Marcus Ramberg shows us how his Perl scripts interfaces with it using  Mojolicious.

entries.title: Elasticsearch Custom Scoring
entries.text: Elastiscsearch default scoring doesn't quite do it for your special case? Despair not, for mateu shows us here how to tweak the scoring algorithm in any way we want.
Mistake, or sinister conspiracy to mask Perl's terrible secrets? Sinan Unur unearthes hidden lore about the 'open' function from Perl's git history.
entries.title: Why was documentation for open FILEHANDLE removed from perlfunc?

entries.text: While crafting a Perl quine, Sinan Unur came across a very peculiar corner case bug of autodie.
entries.title: A bug in Perl's autodie
The Hacker News API
entries.text: Neil Bowers released a Perl interface to the Hacker News API. It's new, it's basic but, and that's the important part, it's there and working; patches will eventually take care of the rest.

entries.title: Synchronizing Opera bookmarks with Perl, Org, and git
entries.text: A little bit of glue can do wonders to tie systems together. Here, perlancar shows us a script he's using to turn his browser's bookmarks in a git-monitored syncable Org document.
In the scientific world "now that's funny..." usually announces a major breakthrough. In the Perl world, as Sinan Unur illustrates, it's typically a harbinger of golfing fun.
entries.title: How does open 0; print <0>; turn every Perl program into a quine?
Tony Cook's Grant Extended
entries.text: Tony Cook will be able to dedicate 400 more hours on the noble task of maintaining Perl 5, Karen Pauley reports.
Paul Johnson reports on his awesome Devel::Cover work (tl;dr? just go to cpancover.com and stare at the covered beauty of it all).

2014.40: Weekly changes in and around Perl 6
